intro: Oxygyne, commonly known as the water plantain, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Alismataceae. It is characterized by its broad, floating or submerged leaves and small, white or greenish flowers. These plants typically thrive in freshwater environments such as ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams. Oxygyne species are often used in wetland restoration projects due to their ability to improve water quality. Their rhizomes can spread rapidly, forming dense underwater vegetation that provides habitat for aquatic life.
